root: ^This bottle of poison you found in the chef's room, Captain, this is the exact contradiction we're talking about.
^Just think about it, Captain. If Chef Sullivan really were the murderer, would he have left such a blatant piece of evidence behind in his room?
^It's almost too convenient, isn't it? A chef, angry about losing his job, leaving a bottle of poison in his drawer?
^That is... a valid point, Detective. But...

^Furthermore, the chef is a smart man. Would he really risk his freedom, his life, by not only murdering Mr. Jenkins but also Ms. Palmer? Two murders in such a short span... It's a heavy price to pay just to keep a job, wouldn't you agree, Captain?
^It does sound... excessive when you put it that way. But then, who...?
^That's exactly what we need to figure out, Captain.
^There's also the possibility that Chef Sullivan has been framed, Captain.

c-0: ^The steward played a role in this.
^That's absurd, Mr. White! The steward herself was a victim!
^You've yet to provide any reason or motive for her to frame the chef.
c-1: ^I propose that Miss Thompson, the maid, had a part to play in it.
^What possible motive could she have, Detective?
^She’s worked for the family faithfully for years.
^You're trying to cast suspicion on everyone, it seems.
^You're right, let me think that through again.
c-2: ^To answer those questions, Captain, we need to consider the origin of the poison.
^The origin? You mean, where it came from? Do you have any leads on that?
^Indeed, I do. And they point towards a particular individual. The younger son of the late Mr. Jenkins - Jonathan.
^Detective, I must say I'm glad to hear someone else voice these suspicions. I've had my own doubts about young Mr. Jenkins.
^Is that so, Mr. Anderson? And why is that?
^Jonathan has always been a bit of an odd one. Keeps to himself mostly. He never seemed to fit into the family, always out of place. You see, he detests the merchant family lifestyle.
^It's more than just detest, Detective. Jonathan and his father... they've had quite the tumultuous relationship. There was an incident last year...
^Well, they had a falling out. A public one. Jonathan lost control, began shouting at his father about the family's disregard for anyone but themselves. It was... quite the scene.
^That's interesting. And how would he have gained access to the poison?

^That's just it, Detective. Jonathan has always had an interest in chemistry, ever since he was a child. His father supported this interest and as a result, he's well-versed in all sorts of substances.
^And you think he would use that knowledge to...?
^It's entirely possible, Detective. Given his knowledge of chemistry, he is the only one with the ability to produce or procure something as deadly as cyanide.
^His motive could be clear. But what about his method, Mr. Anderson? How would he have managed to poison his father's food?

^That's something I can't answer, Detective. But given the circumstances and his clear motive, I believe Jonathan is our prime suspect. His resentment towards his family, his knowledge of deadly substances, the turmoil with his father... it all points to him.
^So, Detective White, are you now convinced of young Jonathan's involvement in this tragic event?
